content.webTitle: Jo Brand apologises for 'crass and ill-judged' battery acid joke

fields.headline: Jo Brand apologises for 'crass and ill-judged' battery acid joke
fields.bodyText: Jo Brand has apologised for her on-air joke about throwing battery acid at politicians. The gag, aired on Tuesday, about throwing the substance at “unpleasant characters” instead of milkshakes, was the subject of a police complaint about incitement to violence. It was also criticised by Nigel Farage – who had a milkshake thrown on him while campaigning in Newcastle during the EU elections – and Theresa May, among others. Brand is reported to have apologised to an audience in Henley, in Oxfordshire, on Thursday, the same day as Scotland Yard said it was investigating the comedian after receiving a complaint. “Looking back, it probably was somewhat a crass and ill-judged joke that might upset people,” the Sun quoted Brand as saying. “Of course I’d never do anything like that. It was purely a fantasy. I’m sorry.” However, she reportedly added she did not think it was a mistake, while acknowledging that others might disagree. Brand also stressed she did not mention Farage by name and that female politicians and public figures faced “far worse” threats on a daily basis. Farage, the Brexit party leader, had accused her of inciting violence and urged the police to act although it is understood that neither he nor his party made the official complaint. Brand made the offending comment on the BBC Radio 4 Heresy programme in response to a question about the “terrible time” in politics that the country was going through. She said: “Well, yes, I would say that but that’s because certain unpleasant characters are being thrown to the fore and they’re very, very easy to hate and I’m kind of thinking: ‘Why bother with a milkshake when you could get some battery acid?’” It was met with roars of laughter from the audience, before she clarified: “It’s purely a fantasy, but I think milkshakes are pathetic, I honestly do, sorry.” Heresy’s host, Victoria Coren Mitchell, said at the end of the show that she hoped Brand’s comments had not caused offence. She later responded to Farage’s tweet complaining about them saying: “I would totally have had you down as a free speech man. Especially when it comes to jokes.” May’s official spokesman said the BBC should explain why it was appropriate content for broadcast. The corporation has said it regretted any offence caused and announced it would be editing the programme to remove Brand’s joke from its online streaming service and any future airings. As of Friday afternoon, Ofcom said it had received 287 complaints about Heresy.
